metadata.case_name: Nearest Reversioner v. Setra Veeravva and Sesalvada Kotra Basayya

facts.text: Kari Veerappa executed will Exbt. P-2 on October 10, 1920, authorizing wife Setra Veeravva (first defendant) to adopt a son for continuation of family, with approval of five trustees mentioned in paragraph 14.
Veeravva made first adoption attempt in 1939, but adopted boy died; validity questioned but not pursued.
Agreement to adopt second defendant (Sesalvada Kotra Basayya) executed as Exbt. D-25 on September 18, 1942; stated Veeravva to remain in possession during lifetime.
Veeravva adopted second defendant on October 11, 1942; deed of adoption registered June 23, 1943.
Appellant, claiming as nearest reversioner of Kari Veerappa, filed Original Suit No. 39 of 1943 for declaration that adoption invalid.
District Judge Bellary dismissed suit on November 26, 1945.

Madras High Court dismissed appeal No. 55 of 1946 on March 25, 1949, affirmed District Judge substantially, held appellant a reversioner but not nearest proved; granted certificate on substantial question of law re adoption validity.

Veeravva in possession of estate since Kari Veerappa's death, recovered via decree in OS 20/1921; written statement para 6 states sole possession up to date despite adoption, subject to her lifetime enjoyment.
Second defendant affidavit admits Veeravva in possession per 1942 agreement.
Appellant affidavit states understanding that second defendant in possession, but not asserted as personal knowledge.
Hindu Succession Act, 1956 came into force on June 17, 1956.

legal_issues.text: Is the adoption of the second defendant invalid, as the approval or consent of the five trustees mentioned in paragraph 14 of the will of Kari Veerappa was not obtained and is the authority to adopt at an end if any one of those five persons did not accept the trusteeship or died before the adoption or refused to give their approval?
Does Section 14 of the Hindu Succession Act, 1956 apply to render Veeravva full owner of the estate, making the suit not maintainable even if adoption invalid?
What is the meaning of 'any property possessed by a female Hindu' in Section 14(1) - actual physical possession or broader including constructive possession?

petitioner_arguments.text: Adoption invalid without approval of five trustees per will.
Section 14 HSA does not apply as estate in possession of second defendant, not Veeravva; she got restricted estate under will and ante-adoption agreement Exbt. D-25.
Power of adoption derived from husband's authority or agnates' consent, not ownership; reversioner can challenge invalid adoption bringing stranger during widow's lifetime.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Hindu law; Specific Relief Act S.42 Ill. f

respondent_arguments.text: Preliminary objection: Suit fails under S.14 HSA; if adoption valid, plaintiff loses; if invalid, Veeravva full owner, no limited estate for reversioners to protect.
'Possessed by' in S.14 means ownership/constructive possession, not mere physical; Veeravva in possession per agreement, written statement, affidavit.

court_reasoning.text: High Court question on adoption validity need not be considered due to S.14 HSA; appellate court can consider change in law.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Lachmeshwar Prasad Shukul v. Keshwar Lal Chaudhuri

court_reasoning.text: 'Any property possessed by a female Hindu' in S.14(1) interpreted broadly: includes constructive possession, possession in law, not just physical; Veeravva possessed estate at Act's commencement via permissive possession of second defendant if adoption invalid.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Possession means state of owning or having in one's hands or power; follows Andhra, Calcutta views over some Patna cases.

court_reasoning.text: No restricted estate under S.14(2): will para 4 conditional on disagreement (not shown); para 12 devolves on intestacy if invalid adoption; agreement Exbt. D-25 confers no estate.
Reversioner right under Specific Relief Act S.42 limited to limited owners, not full owners; suit not maintainable.

holdings.text: Even assuming invalid adoption, Veeravva became full owner under S.14(1) HSA as she possessed the estate (constructively) when Act commenced.
'Possessed by' in S.14(1) includes constructive possession in law.

precedents_cited.case_name: Lachmeshwar Prasad Shukul v. Keshwar Lal Chaudhuri
precedents_cited.relevance: Appellate court entitled to consider change in law.

precedents_cited.case_name: Rama Ayodhya Missir v. Raghunath Missir
precedents_cited.relevance: Patna view on S.14 removing reversioners' rights (not followed).

precedents_cited.case_name: Mt. Janki Kuer v. Chhathu Prasad

precedents_cited.relevance: Dissented from Patna; Act for females, not alienees.
Overruled prior Patna; Act enlarges limited to absolute for possessors.
'Possessed' includes actual, constructive or legal possession at commencement.

statutes_cited.name: Hindu Succession Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Converts limited estate to full ownership for possessed property; 'possessed' broadly interpreted; (2) inapplicable here.

statutes_cited.name: Specific Relief Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Reversioner's right to challenge alienations limited to limited owners, not full owners.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; suit not maintainable under S.14 Hindu Succession Act as Veeravva became full owner even if adoption invalid; no need to decide adoption validity.

key_quotes.text: 'possessed in s. 14 is used in a broad sense and in the context possession means the state of owning or having in ones hand or power.'
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core interpretation of S.14(1) enabling application.

key_quotes.text: The opening words in property possessed by a female Hindu obviously mean that to come within the purview of the section the property must be in possession of the female concerned at the date of the commencement of the Act.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Adopts wide meaning of possession from Gostha Behari case.

key_quotes.text: under the Act Veeravva becoming a full owner of her husbands estate, the suit could not succeed and the appeal must accordingly fail.
key_quotes.speaker: court
